datafield.subfield: One important difference between relativistic systems and non-relativistic systems (such as the ones we consider here), is that for relativistic system one has causality causality: information cannot travel faster than the speed of light. In lattice systems there is no such natural bound. Correlations can, in principle, spread arbitrarily fast. Nevertheless, under suitable conditions, most notably on the locality of the dynamics, there is a maximum velocity in the system, which dictates how fast information can propagate through the system. This is essentially what a Lieb-Robinson bound Lieb-Robinson bound is.
